clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluation of an Innovative Speech-enabled Translator in Emergency Settings
clinical_study.official_title: Evaluation of an Innovative Speech-enabled Translator in Emergency Settings

brief_summary.textblock: Survey-based satisfaction, performance and technical features evaluation of a speech-enabled fixed-phrase translation tool (BabelDR) in an emergency department.

primary_outcome.measure: Satisfaction evaluation through a 4-point scale survey
primary_outcome.description: Are patients' and doctors' satisfied with the use of BabelDr?

primary_outcome.measure: Efficacy evaluation through a 2-point scale survey
primary_outcome.description: Can BabelDr be efficient tool in an emergency context: are doctors' able to reach a diagnostic with the tool?

primary_outcome.measure: Technical features evaluation through a 4-point scale survey
primary_outcome.description: Are the technical features appreciated by the doctors'?

intervention.description: Doctors use a speech-enabled fixed-phrase translation tool to help communicate with an allophone patient.

study_pop.textblock: 30 patients were recruited with an average age of M=38.2 (SD=16.49) of which 53.33% were males. The distribution between the different languages was the following: Spanish (11), Arabic (4), Farsi (7), Tigrinya (7) and Albanian (1).

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- As per inclusion criteria, patients were required to have no understanding of French, thus making a diagnostic interview by the doctors impossible.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Exclusion criteria concerned patients who shared a common language with the doctor and/or were not able to read in their native language.
